awd_titl_txt: BEE:  Mechanisms and Scope for Adaptive Rescue in Polymorphic Populations
awd_abstract_narration:
One of society's great challenges centers on how to maintain biodiversity during the ongoing period of rapid global environmental change. Although plants and animals can respond to environmental change by moving to a different area, they could also adapt in place through either plasticity (e.g. by changing behaviors to match the conditions) or by rapid evolutionary change via natural selection. The option of rapid adaptation in place via plasticity or evolution remains relatively unstudied. Research in this area is critical because the fate of wild species in a rapidly changing environment will depend in large part on the scope of this adaptive rescue.  For 21 bird and mammal species globally, survival depends on camouflage arising from seasonal color molts from brown to white to track the winter presence of snow. Because a decreasing winter snow duration is one of the most pervasive outcomes of ongoing climate change, these animals increasingly find their winter white camouflage compromised against increasingly brown snowless backgrounds. This research will use field studies, captive experiments, and genetic analyses with snowshoe hares as a model to provide general scientific insights to foster adaptive rescue - and therefore biodiversity persistence - in a changing world. 

This study will evaluate the scope for adaptive rescue to climate change in a visually compelling model system based on polymorphic snowshoe hare populations with sympatric winter brown and winter white individuals. Field studies (including radiotagging wild animals) will directly measure fitness costs and behavioral plasticity for the sympatric winter color morphs. Captive experiments with the polymorphic hares will quantify the scope for hares to recognize their own coat color mismatch and behave to reduce either mismatch or risk of predation. Collectively, the field and captive experiments will form the basis of a mechanistic map linking genotype and trait phenotype in a polymorphic population to mean fitness and population growth, while explicitly accounting for behavioral plasticity and the dispersal of adaptive phenotypes.In addition to these contemporary measures of natural selection and behavioral plasticity, georeferenced snowshoe hare specimens archived in natural history collections will facilitate genetic tests for temporal evolutionary responses in the alternative camouflage phenotypes. Overall, this research program links ecological and evolutionary drivers of seasonal camouflage in snowshoe hares and provides a framework to predict how adaptive variation at this fitness-critical trait will respond to future environmental changes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of society’s great challenges centers on how to maintain biodiversity during the ongoing period of rapid global environmental change.  Although plants and animals can respond to change by moving to a different area, they could also adjust in place through either ‘plasticity’ (e.g. by changing behaviors to match the conditions) or by rapid evolutionary change via natural selection.  The scope and underlying bases for such adjustments to sustain biodiversity (e.g. through “adaptive rescue”) remains relatively unstudied.

To address this gap, we previously developed a powerful and visually compelling study system based on 21 bird and mammal species globally whose survival depends on shifting their camouflage from summer brown to winter white to track seasonal snow. Because decreasing winter snow duration is one of the most pervasive outcomes of ongoing climate change, these animals increasingly find their winter white camouflage compromised against increasingly brown snowless backgrounds (see FIGURE 1). We previously found that coat color mismatch in snowshoe hares is deadly, as white animals stick out like white light bulbs to predators. Further, in two previous papers in Science we determined that over evolutionary time coat-color changing species have been gifted (in some cases by between-species hybridization at the end of the last ice age) with adaptations that include genes that code for a winter brown coat, which could help animals survive decreasing snow duration by skipping entirely the winter white color molt.

What is the promise and potential for such legacies from the evolutionary past to predispose wild animal species to survive and persist in today’s changing climate? This research project comprehensively deployed field studies, captive experiments, and genetic analyses to answer these questions and provide practical insights into how policymakers could help foster adaptive rescue for biodiversity. Much of the fieldwork focused on snowshoe hares in an unusual population in the Cascade Mountains of Oregon where both winter brown and winter white color individuals co-exist (FIGURE 1). Here we could use radiotelemetry and remote cameras to directly compare survival, movement, and other responses of winter brown vs winter white hares; we also conducted controlled behavioral experiments to assess the extent to which hares could recognize their own color mismatch and behave so as to reduce mismatch and its consequences.

Crucial to our success has been a multidisciplinary approach that links the field studies with cutting-edge molecular biology, and that also includes a collaborative approach to leverage existing datasets and museum samples globally. The team’s genetic approach uses the same genomic technologies used to study human diseases to decode the basis of adaptation to climate change that already exists in the genes of multiple species globally. Using this approach we have gained novel insights into how climate change-adaptive traits arise (for example, both the timing of the change in the winter white coat and the basis of the alternative winter brown coat), how they persist, and the potential scope for local adaptation in the face of climate change.

One high profile example of general scientific insights that could help foster adaptive rescue in a changing world is described in our recent (2023) Science paper on another hare species, the white-tailed jackrabbit. Here we show that the genetic basis of this species’ adaptations to climate change can be nurtured by actions to both increase the persistence of declining winter brown populations (threatened by habitat loss, predator community shifts, and disease).

Notably, the scientific insights from this project (including more than 15 scientific publications, 14 scientific presentations, and prolific mentoring of students and engagement with the media and policymaking entities) are not specific to the species studied but rather generalizable for wild animal species. The project has an international profile, with collaborators around the world contributing to our work on arctic fox in Sweden (FIGURE 3), weasels in northern Europe (FIGURE 4), and hares in Scotland (FIGURE 5) – all underlying an emerging platform of fundamental principles to guide implementation of practical efforts to maintain wild animal species in a changing world.

      One measure of impact of this project is its high interest to the general public and policymakers. Media coverage in film form has included David Attenborough’s Life in Color Series on Netflix (2021) and another Netflix show (“Earthscape”) to be released in 2024. Coverage in print media has included an article in India’s 2nd largest English news daily (2022), a UK children’s magazine (FIGURE 6), and multiple spotlights in scientific journals and reviews. The project’s scientific output has been cited in the U.S. National Climate Assessment, and in publications of the IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change).  Student mentoring has also been considerable, with 7 graduate students and more than 18 current and past undergraduates supported in part by this grant.
